publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Which No Body can deny
Ye People of Jreland Both Country & City
Come Listen with Patience & hear out my dity
At this time Jll chuse to be wiser than witty
«LD»Which no body

2
The half·pence are coining the nations undoing
There's an end of yr ploughing and baking & brewing
In short you must all go to rack & to ruin
«LD»Which no body

3
Both high men and low men & thick men & tall men
And rich men & poor men & free men & thral men
Will suffer and this man & that man & all men
«LD»Which no body

4
The soldier is ruind poor man by his pay
His five pence will prove but a farthing a day
For Meat & for Drink or he must run away
«LD»Which no body

5
When he pulls out his two pence ye tapster says not
That ten times as much he must pay for his scot
And thus the poor soldier he must go to pot
«LD»Which no body

6
If he goes to ye baker ye baker will huff
And twenty pence have for a half peny Loaf
Then Dog rogue and rascal & so kick & Cuff
«LD»Which no body

7
Again to ye Market when ever he goes
The Butcher and soldier must be mortal foes
one cuts of an ear ye other a Nose
«LD»Which no body

8
The Butcher is stout & he values no swager
A Cleaver's a match any time for a Dagger
And a Blue sleeve may give such a cuff as may swagger
«LD»Which no body

9
The Beggars themselves will be broke in a trice
when thus their poor farthings ar sunk in yr price
when nothing is Left they must Live by their Lice
«LD»Which no body

10
The Squire whos got him twelve thousand a Year
o Lord what a Mountain his rents woud appear
shoud he take em he woud not have house room I fear
«LD»Which no body

11
Tho at present he live in a very large house
There wou'd not be room left in it left for a mous\edge\
But ye Squier too wise he wont take a souce
«LD»Which no body

12
The Farmer who Comes with his rent in ys Cash
For taking these Counters & being so rash
will be kickd out of doors himself and his Trash
«LD»Which no body

13
For in all the Leases yt ever we hold
we must pay our Rent in good silver & Gold
And not in brass tokens of such a base mould
«LD»Which no body

17
The wisest of Lawyers swear they will warrant
No mony but silver & Gold can be currant
And since they will swear it we all may be sure ont
«LD»Which no body

14
And I think after all it woud be very strange
To give current mony for base in exchange
Like a fine Lady Swabbing her Moles for ye mange
«LD»Which no body

16
But read the Kings patent & then you will find
That no man need take em but who has a min\edge\
for which we may say his Majesties kind
«LD»Which no body

17
Now god bless the Draper who opened our Eye\edge\
J am sure by his Book that ye writer is wise
He shews us the cheat from the End to ye Rise
«LD»Which no body

18
Nay farther he shews it a very hard Case
That this fellow wood of a very bad race
should of all ye fine gentry of Jreland take pla\edge\
«LD»which no body

19
That he and his half·pence should come to weig\edge\ do\edge\
our subjects so Loyal & true to ye crown
But J hope after all they will be his own
«LD»which no body

20
This Book I do tell you is writ for yr goods
And a very good against mr woods
If you stand to g·ather hes left in ye sudds
«LD»Which no body

21
Ye shop·men & Trads·men & farmers go read it
For I think of my soul at this time you will nee\edge\ it
or egad if you dont theres an end of your credit
«LD»which no body
